CHEMICALS

mda

Modern humans must learn how to relate to psychoactives responsibly, treating them with respect and awareness, working to minimize harms and maximize benefits, and integrating use into a healthy, enjoyable, and productive life.

MDA

Timeline

by Erowid


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears near the transition between Erowid's library and informational resources section and the beginning of a detailed entry about the chemical MDA, including its responsible use, history, and timeline; it connects resource links (books, newsletters, support options) with the start of the in-depth "MDA Timeline" content within the broader Erowid database on psychoactive substances.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    1910 MDA first synthesized by G. Mannish and W. Jacobson 1 1939 Animal tests are first performed with MDA. 1 1941 First human trials with MDA as part of an exploration of possible therapies for Parkinsonism. 2 1949-1957 MDA studied as a potential antidepressant and/or anorexic agent by Smith, Klein & French.  More than 500 people were given MDA during the course of this investigation. [More Info] Jan 8, 1953 Harold Blauer dies of an overdose of MDA (code name EA-1298) during an army-sponsored drug experiment.  The army was working to develop new "truth serums" or incapacitating agents and injected Blauer with 500 mg MDA IV. 3 [Details] [More Info] Blauer had checked himself into the New York State Psychiatric Institute for depression following his divorce.  Dr. James Cattell administered MDA injections to Harold Blauer, who died within two hours of his fifth and final injection. Edgewood Arsenal provided MDA to Dr. Cattell as part of a research program exploring the possible use of


                    Context: 
                    This chunk is part of a detailed timeline on the history of MDA from its synthesis in 1910 through early research and human trials, including significant events such as its early medical tests, studies as an antidepressant, and the notable 1953 overdose death of Harold Blauer during army-sponsored experiments. It appears within an Erowid.org article under the "Chemicals > MDA" section, providing historical context and key events related to the development, testing, and controversial research of MDA.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    MDA injections to Harold Blauer, who died within two hours of his fifth and final injection. Edgewood Arsenal provided MDA to Dr. Cattell as part of a research program exploring the possible use of MDA as one of several interrogation tools. Cattell later reported We didn't know whether it was dog piss or what it was we were giving him. Blauer's wife won $18,000 in damages in a legal suit against the state in 1955, but the army successfully hid its involvement.  In 1987, Blauer's daughters win a law suit against the federal government for $700,000 over it's role in their father's death. After Blauer's death, Edgewood terminated its investigation into MDA. See also http://www.leagle.com/decision/19871951660FSupp1291_11728 : Elizabeth BARRETT, As Administratrix of the Estate of Harold Blauer, Deceased, Plaintiff, v. UNITED STATES of America, Defendant. 1957 Gordon Alles describes the MDA experience at a conference in Princeton New Jersey, sponsored by the Josiah Macy, Jr., Foundation.


                    Context: 
                    This passage details the 1953 death of Harold Blauer from MDA injections during army-sponsored experiments exploring the drug's use as an interrogation tool, legal aftermath including lawsuits against the state and federal government, and the subsequent termination of MDA research by Edgewood Arsenal. It falls within the timeline section of the Erowid MDA page, which chronicles key historical events in MDA's synthesis, research, regulation, and use.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    Deceased, Plaintiff, v. UNITED STATES of America, Defendant. 1957 Gordon Alles describes the MDA experience at a conference in Princeton New Jersey, sponsored by the Josiah Macy, Jr., Foundation.  The proceedings of the conference were published two years later (1959) in Neuropharmacology: Transactions of the 4th Conference . 1 1958-1961 MDA is patented by several different groups...as a cough suppressant by H.D. Brown (1958), as an ataractic by Smith, Kline, and French, Co. (1960), and as an appetite suppressant under the trade name "Amphedoxamine" (1961). 2 May 17, 1961 Dr. Alexander Shulgin first tries MDA at a dose of 4.8 mg.  After this single dose Dr. Shulgin would not try MDA again until four years later in 1965. 4 [Details] [More Info] 5/17/61  4:40AM  4.8 mg    oral. not unpleasant taste - no mental effects - went like house afire cleaning up lab - organizing - full of energy - this may be an amphetamine-like response or maybe was is normal for this day. no pulse - no


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears in the middle of a detailed timeline outlining the history of MDA, specifically covering events from 1957 to 1961: Gordon Alles's description of the MDA experience at a 1957 conference, multiple patents granted for MDA as a pharmaceutical (1958–1961), and Dr. Alexander Shulgin's first self-experimentation with MDA in 1961. The content is part of Erowid's comprehensive chronology of MDA's synthesis, research, therapeutic exploration, legal status, and early use.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    taste - no mental effects - went like house afire cleaning up lab - organizing - full of energy - this may be an amphetamine-like response or maybe was is normal for this day. no pulse - no eye-pupil change. probably no effect. no more for the moment. 1963-1964 MDA begins showing up in the counterculture. 1 Oct 1967 The U.S. Bureau of Drug Abuse Control reports in its publication Micro-gram their "first encounter with the compound [MDA]". 5 [Details] [More Info] METHYLENEDIOXY AMPHETAMINE  (MDA) In October 1967, we received a capsule, pink at one end and clear at the other, filled with 150 mg. of a white crystalline substance. Dr. Albert R. Sperling, Bureau of Science, analyzed the substance and identified it as 3,4 methylenedioxyamphetamine. This was our first encounter with the compound. Copies of Dr. Sperling's spectra of the free base and the sulfate are attached. Over the past months, BDAC Agents and police have purchased the powder and capsules in the New York area sold as


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears in the timeline section detailing MDA's history, specifically documenting its early countercultural emergence in the 1960s and the first official law enforcement encounters with the substance. It highlights the U.S. Bureau of Drug Abuse Control's 1967 identification of MDA in seized capsules and powders, and their analysis of its chemical structure, situating these events between the first user reports and subsequent legal regulation.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    Copies of Dr. Sperling's spectra of the free base and the sulfate are attached. Over the past months, BDAC Agents and police have purchased the powder and capsules in the New York area sold as mescaline. A clandestine "laboratory" was seized in New York, with 3-1/4 pounds of HDA and 25 pounds of 1,2 methylenedioxy-4-(2-nitropropenyl) benzene, a precursor one step removed from MDA. Attached is determination and identification data on MDA evidence analyzed by Mr. Richard Fox, an analyst in FDA's New .York District. An infrared spectrogram is also shown in STADTLER STANDARD SPECTA, Midget Edition, Spectrum No. 20160. Oct 27, 1970 The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act is passed.  Part II of this is the Controlled Substance Act (CSA) which defines a scheduling system for drugs.  It places most of the known hallucinogens (LSD, psilocybin, psilocin, mescaline, peyote, cannabis, & MDA) in Schedule I.  It places coca, cocaine and injectable methamphetamine in Schedule II.


                    Context: 
                    This chunk appears in a detailed timeline of MDA's history, specifically describing law enforcement's early encounters with MDA in 1967, including the identification, seizure of precursors, and analytical methods used. It transitions into legislative developments, including the 1970 scheduling of MDA and other hallucinogens under the Controlled Substance Act.

metadata.title: Erowid MDA Vault : Timeline
metadata.description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA

content:
Drug: MDA | cid: 1614
Source: erowid | Source description: A timeline of events in the history of MDA
Erowid name: mda
Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    It places most of the known hallucinogens (LSD, psilocybin, psilocin, mescaline, peyote, cannabis, & MDA) in Schedule I.  It places coca, cocaine and injectable methamphetamine in Schedule II.  Other amphetamines and stimulants, including non-injectable methamphetamine are placed in Schedule III. 1980-2000 MDA continues to be used recreational, often sold in tablet form as 'ecstasy'.


                    Context: 
                    This passage appears in a chronological timeline detailing the history and legal status of MDA, describing changes in U.S. drug law in 1970—including the placement of MDA and other substances into specific controlled substance schedules—and notes that MDA continued to be used recreationally through the 1980s and 1990s, often sold as ecstasy.

Category: CHEMICALS
Field: History

                    Text: 
                    References

Stafford P. Psychedelics Encyclopedia. Ronin. 1992.

Pentney AR. "An Exploration of the History and Controversies Surrounding MDMA and MDA". J Psychoactive Drugs. Jul-Sep 2001;Vol 33(3).

Lee MA, Shlain B. Acid Dreams: The CIA, LSD and the Sixties Rebellion. Grove, 1985.

Shulgin AT. Pharmacology Notes I. Page 37.

Microgram Editors. "Methylenedioxy Amphetamine". Microgram. Bureau of Drug Abuse Control. Feb 1968. 1(5):4-5.
